Removed reviewer Jayanth Othayoth <ojayanth@gmail.com>.
JS: Do we really need this trace?
I can remove
Done

Do we need to recursively walk all sub directory and creates the dump?

I think systemd just put in the specified directory, right?

(no harm, just checking)
following original code from core_manager.cpp, I do not know the complete requirement here. but I guess you are correct, but will leave as is as I do not know the history.
Done
took original code from core_manager.cpp but yes we can improve
Done
collecting the BMC dump with?
it is either user, core, checkstop, rmoops dump
Done
collect the BMC dump?
may be BMC core dump
Done
JS: createBMCDumpForCoreFiles?
checkAndCreateCoreDumps leaving as is, internally bmc dump can be core, user, checkstop and rmoops so..

- are deleting the core file after the BMC dump is collected? If so, can you point to the code (could not find it) just checking for "whether we will collect the BMC dump again for the collected core files?" since you are adding in the restore path and currently, the dump monitor just watching for a new core file and requesting to collect a BMC dump with all core files. - Correct me If I am wrong.

- How the application (who wants to offload) knows that we have created a new BMC dump for the core files since in the restore path we are not emitting the D-Bus object create signal, right? (You are trying to fix the dump manager core cases so, checking the offload path)
corefile - plugin does the copy and remove
Done
Can you please include the test case of the D-Bus emit signal?

I think still, we won't emit a D-Bus object creation signal because the D-Bus service name was requested after the restore call. can please confirm it?

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/blob/master/dump_manager_main.cpp#L93

FYR: https://www.stwcx.xyz/blog/2022/04/01/sdbusplus-object-signals.html
Done
JS: You could move LN 288 and this block into the above if block.
Done

Design approaches:
Option 1. Introduce new dump type , which kind of subset type of elog type dump ( refer phosphor-debug-collector/example_errors_watch.yaml xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Error.InternalFailure ). Add new plugin to copy all core files into dump package. Also add important additional info like , journal/ drive in fo etc plugin also in this new dump type.
   During dump manager application start time check core path and create new elog ( which is unique for capture additional core).  
   
option 2: Instead of add new dump type , use user initiated dump and include core files as part of this dump. 
Cons: any user initated dump duing boot/runtime and external user i nitated type is going to copy core files. This can lead confusion incase any core dump packaging is in progress. Also usre initaietd dump is heavy weight  and most of the current data is not relevent for debugging problem.

option 3: call core file level core dump packaging. This can lead performance issue in time and resource. same set of journal data is going to be present in all core dumps. 


Incase of dump quota full use case , i think we don't need to delete cores from the systemd-core path. Systemd-coredump is alway's manages directory specific to core path based on the config setting. default is 10% of max size.
But what is the problem with the current approach? If there is a core file, a dump will be created for that core once the dump manager gets started.

The only problem I see in this is that checking for cores and creating dumps should happen before deserializing and creating entries. If that is done, dumps will be created for each core, and the entries for those will be created during the restore
See comments in line 14.
It is not broken if called before restore, each core will be processed and created a dump and the entries will be created during the restore
See the comment in the code syaing how this is broken from high level.
That looks like a bug
there will be only 1 core file, I tested by crashing the debug collector.

I had tested and see that after a core is generated, core dump file is packaged as part of the dump and removed.

Dec 05 08:38:55 p10bmc systemd[1]: Started Process Core Dump (PID 4001/UID 0).
Dec 05 08:38:55 p10bmc systemd-coredump[4002]: [🡕] Process 4000 (pvm_dump_offloa) of user 0 dumped core.

root@p10bmc:/var/lib/systemd/coredump# ls
core.pvm_dump_offloa.0.c43cfdb15d2b44099942379926cc9301.4000.1670229535000000.zst
root@p10bmc:/var/lib/systemd/coredump# ls

Need to include the additional use case info here.

This is applicable for core monitor crash use case and any application crashes prior to dump manager service starts.
core monitor crash should be a different use case and if required should be handled differently, this commit is to cater for debug collector crash
Done

This approch is broken for multiple core dump use cases. 

Existing core dump type supports processing only one core not supports multiple core inputs. Also deos the special logic to extract additional information from core dump file.
what is multiple core dump use cases? this is to cater for only debug-collector itself crashes and generates core, this core will be ignored as the debug-collector is not around.
Done
This is going to create core type only for first core in the list. All the remaining core is going to ignored. Basically dreport is going to pass first member in the list.
That should be fixed then

This is to cater to only when debug-collector itself cored, so there will be only 1 file. When the application comes back it will pick the core and package it as part of the core dump. For other core dump cases the regular logic should take care.
Done
I think this should happen before restore
Ack
Looks good although the build is failed
will change based on the answer
can we call this as this as part of restore so we can avoid another function enforcement on all derived classes?
Ack

As i mentioned earlier capture dump creates core type for only fisrt core file. 
You can create iterate through the core files and creates dump accordingly will help to all left over core dumps. incase you are going with custom dump type approch like , copy all availble core files into one dump.

Side effect of this approch is missing journal logs specific to the core pid, ApplicationCored type dump capture pid specifc journal at failing context . this can miss in restore path.
can't we fix dreport as it is taking list of files so it should honor that request
dreport plugin is designed to support single core at a time, Basically the dump request trigger is based in file availability.

Each unrelated core file should be in a separate dump, but creating many dumps here may slow down the starting of the service
another approach we can do in the core monitor is to set an event and wait for the dump manager path to be active if it is not available.
Collecting the left-over core dumps should be the responsibility of the core monitor instead of the dump manager right?

Discussed generic design approach here https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/54041/9..30//COMMIT_MSG#b7.  

Incase you want to go with simplest approach , without creating new dump type.
Another approch you can look here is 
- Start  obmc-dump-monitor.service , after xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Manager.service.
-  In the phosphor-dump-monitor  create individual dumps based on each core
-  Start core watch activity after dump creation.

Since the core directory size is systemd policy controlled ,  not seeing much  issues related to  performance, like not expecting too many core files present in the path due to application crashes.
That is what I was suggesting, create the dumps for left over core dumps from the core monitor, not from dump manager
And to cover the crash scenario of dump manager, a wait may be needed when the dump manager is not available

If i need to handle in core monitor which is still running I need to do this
1) Add conficts for core monitor service to dump manager service so when dump manager service goes down core monitor service also goes down
2) During core-monitor restart check for any dumps present in the path and create that many dumps

Is this approach ok?
idle for long time. Rebase and add me back once this is ready for review.
